p: Three of the tested bacteria exhibited some susceptibility to ethanol stem extracts of the plant except S. typhi. But the aqueous stem extracts did not indicate any inhibitive activities against all the bacteria. Higher microbial growth inhibitions were observed with ethanol extracts compared with aqueous extracts. This result may be attributed to the fact that 80% v/v ethanol can extract bioactive compounds with broad range of polarity, whereas water can extract compounds with strong polarity [ 39]. Moreover, the nature of the bioactive constituents may cause differential effects. In this regard, Cowan had confirmed that many plant bioactive compounds with antimicrobial activities are aromatic or saturated organic compounds soluble in ethanol [ 40]. Solvents have great effect on the extraction and efficacy phytochemicals [ 21]. In this case, ethanol is the most common solvent used in extracting plant bioactive substances for medical purposes. Our study has demonstrated that S. incanum stem may not be as good source of bioactive compounds compared with fruits and leaves. As one study with Solanum marginatum L. showed, stem extracts resulted in limited inhibitive activities against bacteria [ 41].
